text.content:
Patient provided with a copy of this Discharge Note.

D/C VITAL SIGNS:
            B/P:  146/74 (06/02/2012 07:35)
          Pulse:  73 (06/02/2012 07:35)
    Temperature:  99.1 F [37.3 C] (06/02/2012 07:35)
   Respirations:  12 (06/02/2012 07:35)
         Weight:  241 lb [109.5 kg] (05/30/2012 13:30)
         Height:  64 in [162.6 cm] (11/20/2011 11:10)
            BMI:  41
           Pain:  0 (06/02/2012 07:35)


Date of Admission: May 30,2012 16:43
 
Date of Discharge: Jun  2,2012
 
Diagnoses Treated: Pseudomonas Pyelonephritis
 
Discharge Diet:
The patient's discharge diet is Diabetic/Carb controlled.
 
 
========================= OUTPATIENT MEDICATION LIST =====================

MEDICATIONS:
Active and Pending Outpatient Medications (including Supplies):
 
     Outpatient Medications                                 Status
=========================================================================
1)   ASPIRIN 81MG EC TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY     ACTIVE
       DAY
2)   CALCIUM CARBONATE 1.25GM (CA 500MG) TAB TAKE 500 MG    ACTIVE
       BY MOUTH THREE TIMES A DAY
3)   CHLORTHALIDONE 25MG TAB TAKE 12.5 MG  BY MOUTH EVERY   ACTIVE
       DAY
4)   CIPROFLOXACIN HCL 500MG TAB TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH     ACTIVE
       EVERY 8 HOURS TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY
5)   ERGOCALCIFEROL 1000 UNIT CAP TAKE 1000 UNITS BY MOUTH  ACTIVE
       EVERY DAY
6)   GLYBURIDE 2.5MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY     ACTIVE
       DAY
7)   LEVOTHYROXINE NA (SYNTHROID) 0.125MG TAB TAKE ONE      ACTIVE
       TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY
8)   LISINOPRIL 20MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY     ACTIVE
       DAY
9)   SIMVASTATIN 80MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY    ACTIVE
       EVENING
10)  VENLAFAXINE HCL 37.5MG TAB TAKE TWO TABLETS BY MOUTH   ACTIVE
       TWICE A DAY

10 Total Medications

ALLERGIES/ADRS:
METFORMIN, CITALOPRAM, FLUOXETINE

Any medication items listed as "pending" are those that have just been
written by your provider(s).  These medication orders will be reviewed by
your pharmacist, prior to the prescription(s) being dispensed. 

The pharmacist will provide you with an updated medication list if needed.

==========================================================================
  Pharmacy has been alerted to provide the patient with discharge
  medication instructions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Heart Failure and Fluid Management: 
  This patient does not have any form of heart failure. 
  This patient is not taking a diuretic. 
  This patient does not require instructions on Fluid Management. 

 
Preventative Health Screens:
  TOBACCO EDUCATION AND SCREENING:

    Quitting tobacco, or never starting, is the most important thing you
    can do to protect your health now and in the future.

    Cutting down on tobacco while you are ill is not enough. 
    Occasional or light tobacco use is still dangerous. 

    Some of the health risks of tobacco use include: 
     - Lung cancer, and other cancers 
     - Heart disease, high blood pressure, and heart attack 
     - Stroke 
     - Vascular disease 
     - Breathing problems (coughing, wheezing, and shortness of 
        breath) 
     - Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) such as 
       Asthma or Emphysema 
     - Infertility in women 

    The benefits of not using tobacco include: 
     - Lower risk for lung and other types of cancer. 
     - Reduces the risk for coronary heart disease, high blood pressure, 
        heart attack, stroke, and peripheral vascular disease. 
     - For those who quit using tobacco, the risk of coronary heart 
        disease risk is reduced within 1 to 2 years of quitting. 
     - Reduces respiratory symptoms, such as coughing, wheezing, and 
        shortness of breath. The rate of decline in lung function is 
        slower among persons who quit using Tobacco. 
     - Reduces the risk of developing chronic obstructive pulmonary 
        disease (COPD), one of the leading causes of death in the 
        United States. 
     - Women who quit using tobacco during their reproductive years 
        reduce the risk for infertility.  Women who stop Tobacco 
        during pregnancy also reduce their risk of having a low 
        birth weight baby. 
     - Cost savings!  Tobacco use is expensive. 
                                 Source: http://www.cdc.gov/tobacco 

    If you use tobacco and decide to quit, we recommend you take 
     these steps: 
      1. Set a quit date; ideally the quit date should be within 
         2 weeks. 
      2. Identify the reasons for, and benefits of quitting; 
      3. Remove all tobacco products from home and work settings; 
      4. Identify and plan ahead for challenges to quitting; 
      5. Get support from family, friends, and co-workers; 
      6. And remember - You can do this!!! 

    Resources for Tobacco users: 
     - Colorado QuitLine: 
         To contact the QuitLine, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW 
         (1-800-784-8669) or visit www.coquitline.org. 
     - Would you like a referral to tobacco cessation classes or 
        therapy? 
         The VA offers this service to you!  Please ask any of our 
         health care providers to assist you in getting enrolled. 
     - Would you like medications to help you quit tobacco? 
         There are smoking cessation medications and nicotine 
         patches that can assist you meet your goal to quit tobacco. 
         The VA also offers this service to you!  Please ask any of 
         our health care providers to assist you in getting a 
         prescription. 
 
 
PHYSICAL ACTIVITY LIMITATIONS
There are no restrictions.
 
Clinic follow up appointments:
  Follow up with your Primary Care Provider (PCP) in 2-4 weeks. 

  If you are unable to get a follow up appointment with your 
  Primary Care Provider in 2-4 weeks, please follow up with our 
  Office Based Medical Team (OBMT) or other urgent care clinic. 
 
  Other follow-up appointment(s) to schedule:
    none
 
  **Clerks: Please complete the appointment times for the requested
  appointments above.

 
PATIENT INSTRUCTIONS:  Patient was instructed to return to the ER if
  fever, chills, abdominal pain, or flank pain
 
Veterans,
Questions may be addressed to our telephone care line
at (303) 399-8020 M-F 8-4pm. Use the touch tone options to direct your
call to a specific department

After hours, the VA Nurse line is available at
1-866-369-8020.

Information about health benefits and services can be found
on the internet by going to the address listed below:
https://www.myhealth.domain/
text.author: NURSE,TWENTY-EIGHT
